title: RSS affiliated outfit challenges Jammu & Kashmir’s special status in Supreme Court, valley smells another conspiracy
text:
RSS affiliated outfit challenges Jammu & Kashmir’s special status in Supreme Court, valley smells another conspiracy By India.com News Desk on October 24, 2015 at 2:09 PM Comments 
Srinagar, October24 : A right-wing, RSS-backed NGO, JK Study Centre had filed a writ petition in the Supreme Court, seeking to scrap the special status granted to Jammu and Kashmir residents. 
Earlier this month a seminar was held in Srinagar by a civil society organisation, Kashmir Centre for Social and Development Studies (KCSDS) advised Kashmiri’s from different professions to defend article 35A, which guarantees special privileges to permanent residents of J&K. Read Also (RSS workers take out armed rally in Jammu, panic grips in old city) 
A noted lawyer Zaffar Shah who was part of the meeting organisded by KCSDS, “If the constitutional provision is carried out, then J&K will lose the special privileges which the constitution offers us. Right to property, right to employment, and right to settlement”. Shah further added that J&K will become like any other state where people from any part of India will have the right to own property. 
The hearing of the petition by the Supreme Court is scheduled on November 3. Prior to that the atmosphere in the valley is already tense after a young man was attacked for allegedly transporting cows for slaughter. Local public committees, trade bodies, civil society are gearing up to form public opinion. 
Article 35 A was extended to J&K by President Rajendra Prasad on May 14, 1954. It was devised to protect to state laws that had been the Maharaja’s rule before independence. 
Prior to this Article 35A has been challenged in the Supreme Court three times. Similar petitions have been dismissed by the Apex Court thrice, in 1956, 1961 and 1970. 
Kashmiri’s believe that there is a huge conspiracy going on against them to scrap article 35 A. The writ petition is widely seen in the valley to damage JK’s special position and force demographic changes in Kashmir in the longer run. 
Observers believe that all eyes are on the coalition government of BJP and People Democratic Party, which has to take a stand in court. 
From various part of the valley, whether its a banned student outfit, of Kashmir High Court Bar association or opposition parties, all have decided to challenge the petition which will be kept in front of a small bench of judges on November 3.
